choices.text: Transposition of Great Arteries.
Endocardial Cushion defects
Pentalogy of Fallot
Coarctation of Aorta

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought in by their mother, who is distressed due to criticism from her mother-in-law regarding the child's health. The child has developmental delays, intellectual disability, and distinctive physical features including sandal gap toes. Recently, the child has been diagnosed with a congenital heart disease. Given the child's clinical features, as shown in the images, what is the most common congenital heart disease associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endocardial Cushion defects

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features of the child is pointing towards the diagnosis of Downs Syndrome. The most common congenital heart disease in case of Downs syndrome is Endocardial Cushion defects (AVSD)

 

The clinical features of Downs syndrome (trisomy 21) are.

Flat facial profile and an upward slant to the eye.

  • Short neck
  • Abnormally shaped ears
  • White spots on the iris of the eye (Brushfield spots)
  • Single, deep transverse crease on the palm of the hand.
    • Brachycephaly
    • Protrudin  g tongue
    • Presenile Alzheimer’s disease.

 

Option A, C and D aren’t the most common congenital heart disease in Downs Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Downs syndrome - Approximately 40% children have congenital heart disease. Endocardial cushion defects account for about 40-60% cases. Presence of heart disease is the most significant factor in determining survival. All children should have a cardiac evaluation before 9 months of age, including echocardiography.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No 610-615.

questions.text: In the pediatric clinic, a concerned mother presents her infant, worried about the child's weight gain. She compares her baby to her sister-in-law's seemingly healthier child. Upon examination, the infant appears active and alert. The mother reports that the birth weight was 2600 grams, and currently, the scale reads 5300 grams, indicating that the infant's weight has doubled. As an intern, you recall the standard growth milestones and reassure the mother. Based on standard pediatric growth patterns, at what age is an infant's weight expected to double from birth?
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) 5 months

 

Option D.

 

Weight of an infant doubles by 5-6 months and quadruples by 2 years of age.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The weight of the baby triples by 1 year of age and doubles by 5 months.

 

Option B. The weight of the baby becomes 4 times the birth weight by 2 years of age and doubles by 5-6 months.

 

Option C. The weight of the baby becomes 5 times the birth weight by 3 years of age and doubles by 5-6 months.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 43-51.

questions.text: During a routine clinic visit, a mother brings her 6-year-old daughter for evaluation. The mother reports that the child can climb stairs using alternate feet, ride a tricycle, remember her name and age, but is unable to narrate stories. Given this information, what is the child's most likely developmental age?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 years.

 

Option A.

 

A 3-year-old child can climb up stairs with alternate feet, ride a tricycle, can remember name, age but cannot narrate stories.

A 3-year-old child should be able to do the following things:

  • Ride tricycle

  • Can go upstairs with alternate feet

  • Can form a tower of 9 blocks

  • Can copy a circle

  • Shares toys

  • Known full name and gender

  • Asks questions

 

Explanation:

 

Option B- A 4-year-old child can narrate stories where as a 3-year-old can only ask questions.

 

Option C- A 5-year-old child asks meaning of the words where as a 3-year-old can only ask questions.

 

Option D-A 6-year-old child not only ask questions but also can narrate the daily things in a better manner.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 43-51.

choices.text: Failure of calcification of cartilage
Failure of membranous ossification
Failure of development of flat bones
Failure of development of long bones

questions.text: A pediatrician in a rural healthcare center is approached by a mother carrying her newborn for an initial health check-up. The infant, as observed in the image provided, exhibits significant limb abnormalities. The mother reports that during her pregnancy, she had taken medication from a local healer, which you suspect may have contained Thalidomide due to the timing and nature of the birth defects. Considering the history of maternal medication intake and the clinical presentation of the infant, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Failure of development of long bones

 

Explanation:

 

Phocomelia refers to Failure of development of long bones.

Phocomelia Syndrome (PS)

 

  • Rare birth defects that cause severe birth defects, especially of the upper limbs.
  • The bones of the arms may be extremely shortened and even absent. The fingers of the hands may be fused.
    • Risk factors:
    • Maternal thalidomide therapy.
    • Genetic inheritance.
    • Roberts’s syndrome.
  • An extreme case results in the absence of the upper bones of both the arms and legs so that the hands and feet appear attached directly to the body. This is called tetraphocomelia
  • Other associated anomalies:
    • Encephalocele.
    • Hydrocephalus.
    • Bicornuate uterus.
    • Short neck.
    • Thrombocytopenia.
    • Renal and cardiac anomalies.

 

Other 3 options are incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phocomelia Syndrome is a rare birth defect characterized by underdeveloped long bones, often related to maternal thalidomide exposure, leading to shortened or absent limbs and potentially associated with other anomalies like Encephalocele, Hydrocephalus, Bicornuate uterus, Short neck, thrombocytopenia, renal and cardiac anomalies.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page 1698

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant is brought in by their mother for a routine pediatric evaluation. The child appears alert and active, and according to the mother, the infant has been gaining weight and height steadily since birth. The pediatrician proceeds with a thorough physical examination and notes the following finding. The pediatrician considers various differential diagnoses for this finding. Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with this clinical feature?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MPS

 

Option C.

The given image is suggestive of microcephaly, it is not seen in case of MPS (Mucopolysaccharidoses). MPS typically presents with various skeletal abnormalities and may not necessarily involve microcephaly, making it the least likely cause of the finding in this scenario compared to the other options listed.

 

Microcephaly – Microcephaly is defined as an occipitofrontal circumference more than 2 standard deviations (SD) below the mean for given age, sex and gestation.

 

Option A, B and D are the causes of microcephaly.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. PKU - Infants with PKU can present with microcephaly if the condition is untreated due to the toxic effects of elevated phenylalanine levels on brain development.

 

Option B. Down's syndrome - Children with Down's syndrome often have brachycephaly, which may give the appearance of a smaller head circumference and can sometimes be associated with actual microcephaly.

 

Option D. Fetal Hydantoin syndrome - This syndrome can result from exposure to antiepileptic drugs in utero and is associated with a range of congenital defects, including microcephaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of Microcephaly

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 40.

choices.text: Transposition of Great Arteries.
Tetralogy of Fallot.
Pentalogy of Fallot.
Coarctation of Aorta.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the pediatric clinic with her mother, who is concerned about her daughter's emotional well-being following incidents of bullying at school. The mother reports that her daughter has been ridiculed for her lack of secondary sexual characteristics and absence of menarche. After a thorough history and physical examination, the pediatrician orders an ultrasound, which reveals an infantile uterus and streak ovaries. Further genetic workup indicates a ring chromosome abnormality involving one of the X chromosomes. The pediatrician begins a discussion about starting hormonal therapy to induce secondary sexual characteristic development. During the consultation, the mother inquires about any associated cardiac anomalies that might be present with her daughter's condition. As a pediatrician, which cardiac anomaly would you inform the mother is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coarctation of Aorta.

 

Explanation:

 

The diagnosis based on the history and the Image given is the Turners Syndrome.

In Turners Syndrome CVS abnormalities like coarctation of aorta, bicuspid aortic valve can be seen.

 

Turner syndrome:

 

Clinical features-

  • Short stature
  • Shield chest
  • Webbed neck
  • Wide spread nipples and
  • Short fourth metacarpal

 

 

Associated anomalies-

  • CVS: coarctation of aorta, bicuspid aortic valve
  • Renal: horseshoe kidney.
  • Gonads: gonadal dysgenesis, gonadoblastoma.
  • Strabismus
  • Cataract.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Ultrasound pelvis reveals hypoplastic uterus and streak ovaries.
  • Karyotype is indicated in all turner syndrome to exclude presence of Y chromosome (associated with gonadoblastoma).
  • Echocardiography and ultrasound for kidney for screening of cardiac and renal abnormalities.
  • Managements:
  • GH therapy (0.1-0.15unit/kg/day)

 

Option A, B and C are not the most common CVS abnormality in case of Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is a condition characterized by the presence of a single X chromosome (45, X karyotype) or a structural abnormality of one of the X chromosomes, such as a ring chromosome. Coarctation of the aorta is a common cardiac anomaly associated with Turner syndrome, occurring in approximately 10-20% of individuals with the condition. It involves a narrowing of the aorta, which can lead to hypertension and an increased workload on the left ventricle.

 

Ref: Essential pediatrics by OP Ghai 9Th Edition – Page No-637

questions.text: An 11-month-old infant named Ramya is brought in by her mother due to concerns about delayed tooth eruption. Ramya's mother compares her to a cousin of the same age who already has several teeth, while Ramya has yet to have any teeth appear. Understanding the mother's concerns, you explain the typical timeline for tooth eruption and the age at which delayed tooth eruption is considered. At what age should the absence of any erupted teeth be a cause for considering a diagnosis of delayed eruption?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 13 months

 

Explanation

 

Delayed eruption of teeth

 

  • Delayed eruption is usually considered when there are no teeth by approximately 13 months of age (mean + 3 SD).
  • Common causes of delayed eruption of teeth include :- (MNEMONIC – FRIED CAP)
  1. Familial
  2. Rickets
  3. Idiopathic (Most common).
  4. Endocrine (hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism)
  5. Down syndrome
  6. Cleidocranial dysostosis
  7. Progeria
  8. Individual teeth may fail to erupt because of mechanical block-age (crowding, gum fibrosis).
  • Causes of early exfoliation include:-
    • Histiocytosis X,
    • Leukemia.
    • Idiopathic factors.
    • Cyclic neutropenia.
    • Trauma.
  • Nutritional and metabolic disturbances, prolonged illness, and certain medications (tetracycline) commonly result in discoloration or malformations of the dental enamel.

 

A discrete line of pitting on the enamel suggests a time-limited insult.
 

Educational objective

 

Delayed eruption is usually considered when no teeth have erupted by

approximately 13 months of age. Common causes include congenital

or genetic disorders, endocrine disorders (e.g., hypothyroidism,

hypoparathyroidism), familial conditions, and (the most common) idiopathic

conditions.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition. Page No- From 1198.

questions.text: A 24-month-old child is brought in by their mother for a routine pediatric check-up. The child appears to be developing normally and has recently started to engage in scribbling activities. The mother is curious about her child's developmental milestones and asks you, the pediatrician, about the age at which the child will be able to copy the figure shown to you, which is a circle. Based on your knowledge of childhood development, at what age can a child typically copy a circle?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3 years

 

Option D.

 

The ability to copy a circle is a developmental milestone that most children achieve by the age of 3 years. This activity requires fine motor skills, hand-eye coordination, and the cognitive ability to perceive and replicate shapes, which are typically not fully developed until this age.

 

Important milestones of a 3 years child

  • Rides tricycle
  • Knows his age and sex.
  • Stands momentarily on one foot
  • Repeat a sentence of 6 syllables
  • Draws a circle
  • Has a vocabulary of 250 words
  • Can dress or undress himself completely
  • Counts 3 objects correctly
  • Builds tower of 10 cubes
  • Can withhold and postpone bowel movement

 

Remember –

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 1 year - The child’s pincer Grasp develops by 1 year.

Option B. 2 years - The child starts making vertical and circular strokes by 2 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fine motor milestones development includes the following,

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 43-51.

questions.text: A working mother brings her 3-year-old child to the pediatrician’s office for a routine check-up. On evaluation child is small for her age with a beak-like nose, narrow face, and widely spaced eyes as shown in the image. The mother reports that the child has difficulty feeding due to a small jaw and mouth, and has been slow to reach developmental milestones. The pediatrician diagnoses this as a case of Seckel syndrome. All of the following are features of Seckel syndrome, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Macrocephaly

 

Option B.

 

Seckel syndrome is characterized by intrauterine growth retardation, postnatal dwarfism, and a unique facial appearance except for macrocephaly, which is not associated with Seckel syndrome and thus is the correct answer.

 

Clinical features of Seckel syndrome include:

  • Microcephaly: a circumference that is below the 3rd percentile for their age and gender.
  • Intellectual disability:
  • Facial abnormalities: Features may include a beak-like nose, narrow face, and Micrognathia. The ears may be low set and rotated backward, and the eyes may be widely spaced and/or have a downward slant.
  • Skeletal abnormalities: Bones may be thin and/or abnormally shaped, and joints may be hypermobile.
  • Feeding difficulties
  • Other features:  heart defects, kidney abnormalities, and seizures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A, C and D are the features of Seckel syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seckel (SCKL) syndrome, sometimes called “bird-headed dwarfism,” is an autosomal recessive developmental disorder characterized by marked growth failure and mental deficiency, microcephaly, a hypoplastic face with a prominent nose, and low-set and/or malformed ears. Approximately 25% of patients have aplastic anemia or malignancies.

 

Note - There is broad genetic heterogeneity comprising at least 8 classifiable types: SCKL1, ATR mutation; SCKL2, RBBP8 mutation; SCKL3, maps to 14q21-q22; SCKL4, CENPJ mutation; SCKL5, CEP152 mutation; SCKL6, CEP63 mutation; SCKL7, NIN mutation; and SCKL8, ATRIP mutation.

 

Ref: Nelson 21th Edition, Page No 10133
